metadata.name: Dots #133
metadata.description:
Titled as a play with colors and shapes created from dots, Dots started as a collection on Objkt, extended to 8bidou and had new developments in Exchange Art. It was a dream to be able to make a collection of Dots on Fxhash, now it finally happened. Initially we only had 1 color palette, however, to create more variety, this project has 7 color palettes. To create the palettes we chose 5 famous artists to honor, including Peter Halley, Max Bill, Piet Mondrian, Sophie Taeuber and Lygia Clark, in addition to the palettes created by us. The project has several grids and some new possibilities in addition to the pieces already created on other platforms. It is with great pride and joy that we present this project made with great affection. Enjoy!

Press [S] to save a image

metadata.name: Geometrical #108
metadata.description:
The characteristics of each piece include a different color palette, 5 geometric shapes with random angles, random permutations of each shape, with 2 mirror and non-mirror properties.

- Image Size 4000*4000 Pixels
- Press “s” to save the current canvas.

Artist: Pointiago & Ateliê 407.genart
Oct 24, 2022
License: NFT 2.0

metadata.name: codeTurning 2: push&POPing #32
metadata.description:
The codeTurning project aims to reflect my journey from traditional tools to code, in which any day I learn a new skill.
Join me towards something new for me. Something different from the previous.
Sometimes we will stand on the shoulders of giants.
 
Let's explore and see how far we get.
 
Lesson 2: push&POPing
 
With the sole initial aim of exploring push() and pop(), this stop along the way allows us to delve into the beautiful whimsy of basic colored geometric shapes. I'm having fun.

metadata.name: The Wintertime #89
metadata.description:
"The Wintertime" is a collection of generative art that captures the essence of the winter season in a glitchy and abstract way. The pieces in this collection are a visual representation of the harshness and beauty of winter, where the cold and barren landscapes are juxtaposed against the sparkling snow and ice. The glitches and digital distortions in the art add a sense of chaos and unpredictability, mirroring the unpredictable nature of winter weather. The collection celebrates the winter season in all its raw and untamed glory. Each piece is unique and evocative, inviting the viewer to get lost in the beauty of the wintertime.

The work was inspired by the drip painting technique of Jackson Pollock and the minimalistic elegance of Japanese prints. Combining these two distinct styles creates a visually striking and thought-provoking collection that pays homage to the masters while pushing the boundaries of contemporary art.

This collection is the continuation of GPTree: https://www.fxhash.xyz/generative/17691

Genuary 2023: Recursive trees

To create the palettes we chose 5 famous artists to honor, including Peter Halley, Max Bill, Piet Mondrian, Sophie Taeuber and Lygia Clark, in addition to the palettes created by us. The project has several grids and some new possibilities in addition to the pieces already created on other platforms. It is with great pride and joy that we present this project made with great affection. Enjoy!

Press [S] to save a image

metadata.name: Stepping Stones #95
metadata.description:
"Stepping Stones" is part of the fxhash interactive minting experience at Performance in Code: Deciphering Value in Generative Art, Art Basel Miami Beach, 2022

Stepping Stones explores the idea that the whole is greater than the sum of its parts. Simple patterns, shapes, textures, and colors are arranged in randomly selected ways. Overlaying shapes distort and blend, breaking these objects apart and causing complex forms to emerge. Combining these individual features together results in varying outcomes, from surprisingly simple to wildly chaotic.

---------------

Controls:
Press 1-6 to change the scale of the canvas (1 = default, 2500px x 2500px, 6 = 15,000px x 15,000px)
S (or double tap on mobile): Save output at current size
C: Toggle cutout shapes visibility
H: Toggle cutout outlines visibility
B: Iterate border sizes (none, default, 1.5x, 2x, 3x)
T: Toggle texture visibility
F: Toggle fullscreen
Add the url params x and y to set custom dimensions. For example, add &x=1500&y=500 for a 1500px x 500px image

---------------

Tyler Boswell (@teaboswell) 2022
CC BY-NC-ND 4.0, See bundle.js.LICENSE.txt for third party license information

metadata.name: Gkrint #242
metadata.description:
Gkrint is a celebration of minimalism, colour, and space using the humble grid, a foundation of generative art, and movement. Through this collaboration, Ballzerino and George explore the relationships between these elements.

Inspired by the timeless principles of Bauhaus design, Ballzerino carefully curated custom colour palettes and selected geometric shapes, while George encoded the creative process into an algorithm, bringing the compositions to life, and putting the CPU to work finding new and unexpected compositions within our framework.

Gkrint is Ballzerino's genesis generative art drop.

Controls:
SPACE - pause / resume
click (or tap) - change colour selection (within same palette)
hold 'f' - speed up animation

Tested on Windows / Mac / iOS / Android. Chrome recommended for the best experience.

metadata.name: Splinter #9
metadata.description:
This release marks my first anniversary on the fx(hash) platform! I want to extend a huge thank you to everyone for a fantastic year, and I'm looking forward to many more in the generative-art world!

The basic algorithm is an evolution of the one I used in my first release, Raked Strokes. Instead of mimicking a brush with parallel segments, I'm using perpendicular line segments to define the overall abstract shape and then drawing each line in a simulated media. This approach blends my first attempts at natural media with everything I've learned in the past year.

Viewing in desktop Chrome is recommended for the best results.
Press 's' to save a screenshot. The image size is 2357x3000px
Press 'p' to pause/resume during drawing.

Features
- Base path shape: line, circle, diamond, or rectangle
- Elements defining the spacing and orientation of the line segments
- The base path painted in the background
- Monochrome, dark background, and selection of palettes
- Ink pen styling: thickness, quality, and background blocking
- Paint styling: color distribution, quality
- Shapes: triangle, polygons, criteria for insertion
- Shapes overdrawing: outlines or perpendicular segments

Copyright (c) 2022 Matt Perkins, hello@mattperkins.me, @nudoru on Twitter. Licensed under CC BY-NC-SA 4.0, see LICENSE.txt for more information.

metadata.name: Obliques #12
metadata.description:
Obliques are a reinterpretation of Parallels, a collection of AI generated color fields by Marc Maurer. Many of the pieces in that collection are CC0, which basically means they can be reused for other projects, like this one.

Obliques takes artifacts from Parallels and uses them as brushes, painting slices of the original image on the canvas in a (hopefully) pleasant, chaotic way.

About 10% will be "Glitched".

The "Source Material" property will tell you the name of piece that it is using.

You can see Marc Maurer's Parallels project here:
https://objkt.com/collection/KT1TiSEcASGD19SW8bmqrqgSgCBkwXqDdTJ1

Obliques are also CC0, so feel free use anything here in other projects.

You can read more about CC0 here:
https://creativecommons.org/share-your-work/public-domain/cc0/

G : Toggle Grain
M : Toggle Matte
S : Save Image
1 -> 6 : Set pixel density
(Default pixel density is 1 @ 2000x2000)

metadata.description: An assortment of connection structures used between Bounds constructs and their Junctions

metadata.name: THE400FLIPS #234
metadata.description:
The more they flip. The more you’ll make.

p5.js –> Blockchain


Controls:

[s] save as PNG.
[a] render alternate higher resolution artwork (takes a few seconds).
[z] save alternate artwork as PNG.


Artist note:

Primary royalties are split 95-5% between artist and The Processing Foundation.

Secondary royalties go to the minters (99.9% of the 15%).

The preview thumbnails don’t do justice to the artworks. Please run the code to appreciate them better. Also, remember to check the alternate higher resolution renders using [a].

Some preview thumbnails might look slightly different to the artwork seen when running the code. This is due to the resolution difference between the capture module and the live code on your device. 

Please get in touch in the event of a blank preview thumbnail. 

Made in p5.js and rendered in webGL. Tested on Chrome and Safari.


Copyright (©) 2022 Thomas Noya
Licensed under CC BY-NC-SA 4.0

◉_◉

Press "s" to download a jpg image (if"opened" in full page)

metadata.name: Artifact #10
metadata.description:
This project is about uncovering artifacts.

Each piece is determined by approximately 15 parameters. This allows for a multitude of possible forms, and each iteration is an artifact to be discovered within the multidimensional space.

This work is focused around discovery. It is about exploring the space of the algorithm, shedding light on its many forms, and sometimes finding artifacts of the real world embedded within them.

Technically, this work is a composition of three primary elements: Voronoi tessellations, orthographic projection, and the depth-sort algorithm.
The latter of these is integral to the rendering mechanism. It works intuitively, drawing distant objects before near objects, evaluating the distance of each object according to its geometric center. It does this precisely, and in doing so, it can produce interesting visual artifacts, drawing some shapes in an unexpected order.



This has been a fascinating study, bringing light to unreal shapes and forms, and uncovering artifacts in an impossible space.

I hope you enjoy it,
Nat Sarkissian





Technical Notes:
- Append “&mag=N” to the end of the URL in live mode to specify a resolution multiplier. It will render the image N times larger than the size of your window. If you have specified anything greater than 1, a download will start automatically once the rendering is done.

metadata.name: Conveying Opulence #1
metadata.description:
"and my dreams are composed either by my mind or by chance" - Italo Calvino, Invisible Cities, 1972 

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Take a simple algorithm, arrange basic geometric units by chance, take half of that composition and mirror it, repeat it again and again until opulence is conveyed. 

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

The subtle grain effect is done with p5.grain library by @gorillasu & @meezwhite. 

Look out for the FOMO keyboard key to unlock more variations.
